misconceptions.name: Implemented solution for a different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The program computes average acceleration from three inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads v0, v1, and t and prints the average acceleration, regardless of the stated problem about summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly solve the specified task: read exactly five integers from the user, filter the even ones, sum them, and print that sum. Any other computation, such as average acceleration, does not meet the problem requirements.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers
Only three values are read, and they are treated as doubles representing speeds and time
Output message refers to 'average acceleration' rather than 'Sum of even numbers'
No use of modulus or logic to identify even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copying or reusing code from an unrelated textbook example about physics (average acceleration) instead of implementing the required algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the average-acceleration logic and rewrite the program to match the specification: prompt for five integers, read them (in a loop or individually), check each for evenness using n % 2 == 0, accumulate a sum, and print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every visible part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) is aligned with an average-acceleration example and not with the required sum-of-evens behavior.

evidence.note: Prompt, variables, and output text clearly implement an average-acceleration problem, not the requested sum-of-even-numbers problem.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect number and type of inputs read
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading five integers as required, the program reads only three values and treats them as doubles (v0, v1, t).
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading three double values for v0, v1, and t is an acceptable way to handle the input for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading exactly five integer values from the user. The code should perform five integer reads (e.g., using nextInt()) and not three double reads with different semantics.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
Reads only three values instead of five
Variable names suggest physical quantities rather than general integer inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this task and a different example, leading to reusing input code that does not match the problem's required quantity or data type.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three nextDouble() calls with logic that reads five integers using nextInt(). This can be done either with five separate calls or inside a loop that runs five times.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and three nextDouble() calls are explicit and contradict the problem requirement of five integers.

evidence.note: Shows three double reads (v0, v1, t) instead of five integer reads as required.

misconceptions.name: Misuse of loop and absence of accumulation logic
misconceptions.description: A for-loop runs five times but does not process any input values or accumulate a sum; instead, it repeatedly assigns the same expression to x, making the loop pointless and failing to compute a sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: Including a loop and assigning x inside it, even without using the loop variable or any inputs, is sufficient to meet the requirement for using a loop in the solution.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The loop should iterate over the five inputs, using its index or the values read to perform work each iteration (checking evenness and updating a running sum). Simply reassigning the same expression inside the loop without using iteration variables or inputs does not achieve the required behavior.
symptoms: Loop variable i is never used inside the loop body
Expression for x does not depend on i or any changing state
No accumulator variable is updated to sum values
No conditional logic (like n % 2 == 0) is present inside the loop
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how loops and accumulators work—treating the loop as a formality rather than as a construct that processes a sequence of values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the current loop body with logic that reads or processes each of the five numbers: for each value, check if it is even (n % 2 == 0) and, if so, add it to a sum variable declared outside the loop. After the loop, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The loop body clearly does not depend on the iteration variable or on any input list, and there is no sum or conditional logic, indicating a misuse of looping and accumulation.

evidence.note: Loop runs five times but only reassigns x to the same value, never using i, never summing inputs, and never checking evenness.
